text: I'll continue to fight to rein in wasteful spending. Learn more about my latest efforts to stop government waste here: https://www.paul.senate.gov/news/icymi-hsgac-committee-passes-paul-legislation-help-stop-new-wasteful-spending http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1159082608250298369/pu/img/SfT4Mdm-wGnuOhOy.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1159082608250298369/pu/vid/320x320/KWAW9B0yE8PETwBC.mp4?tag=10

I want Washington to work for communities all over the country—and make sure every community has the resources it needs to thrive. Together, we can make big improvements in the lives of rural Americans.
Agriculture has become one of the biggest polluters in our economy, thanks to decades of failed policy. By paying farmers to fight climate change and investing in R&D we can tackle climate change.

I have plans that will help bring affordable housing, child care, and accessible banking to rural communities. My new approach to trade policy will make sure we're keeping good jobs here in America and giving rural communities a voice in trade negotiations.

A whole bunch of my other plans will help rural communities, too. My plan to cancel student loan debt and provide free public college will help young people build a future in rural communities, instead of driving them to cities to find a job that can pay down their debt.

Here’s my new approach: Guaranteeing farmers a fair price—raising farm incomes and reducing taxpayer expenses. We'll pay farmers for sustainable farming that protects our environment and provide consumers with affordable, local food. https://medium.com/@teamwarren/a-new-farm-economy-8db50fac0551

Finally, I've got a plan to overhaul our country's failed approach to the farm economy. For decades, government policy has subsidized industrial agriculture at taxpayers' expense while driving environmentally unsustainable farming practices and starving farmers.

This ends when I’m president. I'll create a public option for broadband and make sure every home has affordable high-speed internet. I'll crack down on anti-competitive practices and appoint FCC Commissioners who'll restore net neutrality and provide open access to the internet.

One of the best tools to expand access to health care—and unlock other economic opportunities—is high-speed internet. But big broadband companies exclude entire communities—especially tribal communities and communities of color—from fast, reliable internet access.

I'll also tackle consolidation in health care. If a proposed merger is a first step to closing hospitals or slashing basic services, then a Warren administration will block it. And I'll invest more resources in community health centers and closing today’s rural doctor shortage.

My plan starts with protecting access to health care in rural communities, which are rapidly losing access to basic services. That's why I support #MedicareForAll—and why I'll increase Medicare reimbursement rates to help rural hospitals stay afloat.

Everyone should have the opportunity to build a good life wherever they live. But as giant corporations and Washington keep cutting off opportunities for huge parts of the country, the shot to succeed gets further out of reach for rural families. I've got a plan to fix that.

I'm kicking off my Iowa road trip today! As we head into Iowa, I'm sharing my new plans to invest in rural communities. It's time to put their interests ahead of giant companies and Wall Street. https://medium.com/@teamwarren/my-plan-to-invest-in-rural-america-94e3a80d88aa

Two bills we should pass right away which could prevent future terror attacks like the ones this weekend:

1. Our “Red Flag” Law (S.7); &

2. Our Threat Assessment,Prevention & Safety Act (S.265)

#Sayfie #FlaPol  https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/senate-bill/265

Events in #HongKong aren’t an internal matter for #China we should stay silent about. Because the spread of authoritarianism will eventually pose a threat to our own democracy.  

Defending democracy &  hu­man rights is in our national interest. https://www.wsj.com/articles/america-first-needs-democracy-abroad-11565132519

Those who love an offense love a fight; those who build their gate high court disaster.

Psalms 17:19

“There is only one way to get there—and that’s together. 

Only one way to win—with the power, the healing, and the salvation we find in love.” —Cory at Mother Emanuel
“We must now dedicate ourselves, as our ancestors did, to being freedom fighters—for liberty is one of our most sacred civic values.” —Cory at Mother Emanuel
“You can’t lead the people if you don’t love the people—all the people.” —Cory at Mother Emanuel
“It’s with faith in God, in one another, and in who we can be that we come here together today. Not because of hate, but because of love.” —Cory
“When evil showed itself in this church basement four years ago … this church showed us how not to allow hate, when it comes into our lives, to take root in our souls.” —Cory at Mother Emanuel

There is another story we can tell about our country.

Not one that ignores our mistakes or accommodates our failures. 

Not one that glorifies singular heroes or the so-called “great men” of our history. 

A story about who we can be … together.
“We have the power to act. And we can act to legislate safety even if we cannot legislate love.” —Cory at Mother Emanuel
“Because if the answer to the question ‘do racism and white supremacy exist?’ is yes, then the real question isn't who is or isn't a racist, but who is and isn't doing something about it.” —Cory

“Our work is not complete by calling out the shortcomings of our leaders … Each person, each generation has a decision to make: do you want to contribute to our collective advancement or—through inaction or worse—to our collective retrenchment.” —Cory

“The act of anti-Latino, anti-immigrant hatred we witnessed this past weekend did not start with the hand that pulled the trigger … it was planted in fertile soil, because the contradictions that have shadowed this country since its founding remain a part of who we are.” —Cory
"White supremacy allows political leaders to promise to 'build the wall'—while not building hospitals, schools, or infrastructure.” —Cory at Mother Emanuel

“As much as white supremacy manifests itself in dangerous and deadly acts of terror, it is perpetuated by what is too often a willful ignorance or dangerous tolerance of its presence in our society.” —Cory

"Silence in the face of these injustices is a choice. To be passive is to be complicit. To ignore hate is to empower it. 

It is to fall back on that easy false virtue of tolerance.” —Cory at Mother Emanuel
“White supremacy has always been a problem in our American story—if not always at the surface, then lurking not so far beneath it.” —Cory at Mother Emanuel

RT @ABC "White supremacy has always been a problem in our American story."

Sen. Cory Booker says "We need to be honest about not just who we are, but who we have been" in a speech at the Mother Emanuel AME Church where nine worshipers were killed in 2015. https://trib.al/Zhtb7vr http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EBXx-8rU4AIrupD.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1159098352367050752/vid/480x270/oXX2UAjEq0W0oTcx.mp4?tag=13

But it is incredibly important that we recognize that perfectly normal, good people are capable of aiding racism & white supremacy.

Recognizing that is not about pillorying people. It’s about learning to recognize *the virus* & end an oppressive system designed to hurt us *all.*

What this moment is asking of us is to discuss *white supremacy and racism* as much - or possibly more than - *white supremacists and racists.*

When we do that, I believe we will start to make progress.

Recognizing white supremacy in ourselves - our institutions, our subconscious, our own past remarks or acts (no matter how consciously unintentional), is what makes the healing work ahead challenging. 

But it is not impossible,and confronting it is the only way to move forward.

Perhaps more than the obvious last steps of the supremacist,we must examine the nuance of their first steps.

That is a painful inquiry, bc for many, we may see familiarity in those first steps. And that familiarity is very difficult to see + admit. We’d rather not talk about it.

Healing ourselves of white supremacy will be hard. It will be hard because it requires us to confront *ourselves.*

We wish it was as simple as denouncing a white hood, a burnt cross, vile language. But we need to address where supremacy *begins,* not just where it ends.

White supremacy is often subconscious. & Clearly, our nation has not been inoculated. WS is our nation’s original sin;the driving logic of slavery, of Native genocide, of Jim Crow, of segregation, of mass incarceration,of “Send Her Back.”

It never went away. It was just dormant.

There is a difference between white supremacists & white supremacy.

White supremacy is like a virus. 

Supremacists are those who have been completely overcome by the disease, but supremacy - the virus - exists on a larger scale beyond just the infected. It also lays dormant.

America has shown greatness, not because of the absence of violent bigotry and white supremacy, but because of our efforts to overcome it. We must now dedicate ourselves, as our ancestors did, to being freedom fighters—for liberty is one of our most sacred civic values. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1159274684929728515/img/ETkrZL3E6gDfofeE.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1159274684929728515/vid/320x320/SsC8NPe24K7ilY8X.mp4?tag=13

Mitch McConnell and Donald Trump won’t act—but we will. Together, we can stand up to the NRA and demand real gun reform to keep our communities safe. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EBaSMEJXYAAQBvU.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1159273787529076738/vid/320x320/--zenMux7wmJBa0i.mp4?tag=13
